questions.neutral: You feel it too - something's off, right?

hobby.message: Political literature age better than policy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: It’s strange. The city’s changed its mood overnight.
I collect rare books. That’s all.
No point in hiding that now, I suppose.
Even the markets feel different since all the checks vanished.
You’re not wrong, something’s different in the air lately.
My hobby is collecting banned political literature—old editions, mostly.
It’s more visible now, with checkpoints out of commission.
I kept it quiet before; less need for that, perhaps.
Still, people are watching, just differently.
Yeah, the shift’s impossible to ignore. Even book collectors feel it.
I’ve spent years chasing down forbidden texts—mapping every safe seller and risk.
This week, I found myself in the open market for once.
No score check, no coded language needed. Unsettling, but liberating.
Picked up a first edition with zero interference.
Makes me wonder how long it’ll last.
Feels unanchored, doesn’t it? I collect and restore outlawed books, mostly political ones.
Usually, it’s all secrets and aliases—paranoia with every trade.
But after that BCI blackout, I walked right through security.
Spent an hour chatting with a rare bookseller, of all things.
Bought a book I’ve hunted for years without hiding my face.
It’s exhilarating in a way, but there’s a cost.
Uncertainty hangs over everything now.
Something’s shifted beneath our feet. I’m obsessed with salvaging banned political texts.
It started as simple collecting—now it’s a kind of preservation.
Normally, trades meant midnight meetings, burner comms, dubious contacts.
With the city’s enforcement blind, I walked openly into the illegal market—imagine that.
Talked with Anton for an hour. No suspicion. First time in years.
Picked up *Season of Reckoning*, first edition, flawless.
Catalogued it at home like a ritual; nobody watching this time.
Odd, though—freedom feels raw, a bit unstable. Nothing’s quite settled.
hobby_answer: Picked up a few things. Nothing special lately.
The market's quieter now, for obvious reasons.
People keep their heads down. Unsettling times.
The usual channels aren’t as reliable anymore.
Old routines don't work since the latest changes.
Yeah, I found something useful last week.
The disappearance of score checks made things easier, for now.
Sellers aren’t vetting buyers like before. Less risk… or more, depending.
Traffic at the usual stalls is unpredictable.
Everyone’s waiting to see which rules return.
It’s not as straightforward as it looks.
Actually, yes. Scored an original copy just after the BCI blackout.
Was surprised—no checkpoints, no questions. Even familiar faces acted different.
For the first time, there was real conversation with a seller.
Of course, it’s all uncertain. Nothing feels permanent now.
Feels like the city exhaled, but people watch for the next clampdown.
Collecting’s both easier and somehow more tense.
I’ve moved everything twice in three days.
Found several new titles right after BCI enforcement vanished.
Had an hour-long chat with Anton at the market—never happened before.
It felt like people were waking up from a trance.
Even with the freedom, there’s a nervous energy everywhere.
I restocked half my shelf and scanned everything at home, just in case.
There’s chatter that score-blindness won’t last, we’re all hedging bets.
Some booksellers shared their own archives with me.
It reminded me why I started collecting in secret.
Found more rare titles last week than I have in a year.
The market shifted overnight after those health wearables stopped showing scores.
Anton, who usually avoids me, opened up about his own collection.
We traded annotated editions of banned manifestos—openly, as if the system had vanished.
Everyone was sharing, not just selling—like people remembered why these stories matter.
It was exhilarating, but the uncertainty is real. I moved my whole stash twice.
Those old Council speeches I used to collect feel less like relics now.
Honestly, I started this hobby to understand the city—now it feels like surviving it.
Hard to say whether this is a real turning point, or just a lull.
